title: Flag, Faith and Tommy Robinson â€” Former "Far Right" Activist Speaks
description:
Glen Scrivener interviews former right wing activist Harrison Clewes about Tommy Robinson's recent Christmas carols event in London. Harrison tells his story of being, in his words "to the right of Tommy Robinson", coming to faith in Christ and how the church might respond to a renewed interest in cultural Christianity.

title: How to Share Jesus in a Post-Christian Age (Rebecca McLaughlin)
description:
What's special about church? For this final episode, Glen Scrivener and Andrew Wilson are joined by Rebecca McLaughlin, author of "Confronting Christianity" and "The Secular Creed". 

They discuss the unique nature of the in-person church as the place where the vertical dimension of worship meets the horizontal dimension of embodied community. Reflecting on the long history of Christianity, they acknowledge that the church simply 'doing its thing' has a transformative leavening impact on the world.

McLaughlin offers a critique of some of our attitudes towards church and personal evangelism, and some encouragements to keep proclaiming Christ even when it feels fruitless. Scrivener examines how our fear of being labeled 'bigots' can sometimes lead us to disqualify ourselves from sharing the gospel, even though our friends might be more receptive than we imagine. 

The podcast ends on a hopeful note, in that we are actually living in pre-Christian times: Jesus is Lord, he is returning, and summer is coming.

Originally released 5th December 2023 on The Gospel Coalition: https://youtu.be/X-XwixfQBJo?si=a_lUi2UxEM1AkqOT

title: How To Be Properly WEIRD â€” Proclaiming Christ in a Post-Christian Age
description:
How can Christians offer grace, freedom, and truth in this current cultural moment? In this episode, Glen Scrivener and Andrew Wilson get practical. 

If their books are correct in diagnosing the 21st-century West as post-Christian, what impact can this have on our approach to everyday evangelism, preaching, and parenting? They return to the observation that it is refreshing to be able to say to people, "Here's why you're right," rather than, "Here's why you're wrong." 

They tease out the unique challenges of our current context and the need for Christians to offer counter-catechesis. Scrivener shares some examples of fruitful conversations he has had with friends and strangers, and Wilson reflects on how to engage with casual visitors in our churchesâ€”people who might not call themselves Christians but are recognising the radical and foundational nature of Biblical teaching.

Originally released 28th November 2023 on The Gospel Coalition: https://youtu.be/g6eKUw8qh00?si=0tbreKvzKzbmCPZj

title: How Did We Get So Self-Obsessed? (With Carl Trueman)
description:
â€œBe true to yourselfâ€ is a dominant refrain in the Western world, but how has individualism come to be such a prominent feature of Western thought? To what extent is that individualism Christian? 

Glen Scrivener and Andrew Wilson are joined by Carl Trueman, author of "The Rise and Triumph of the Modern Self and Strange New World", to answer those questions and continue their discussion of our post-Christian world. 

Beginning with Rousseau, they trace the ways in which our idea of the modern self has transformed and shaped our understanding of anthropology. Particularly touching on the transformations which have happened in our understanding of marriage, divorce and sex, they ask in what ways the church has become complicit in these changes and to what extent these individualistic assumptions have come to shape both the church and the world.

Originally released 21st November 2023 on The Gospel Coalition: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EpvFZ4tuZ1s&t

title: America Has ALWAYS Been Post-Christian â€” From 1776 to Today
description:
How did the founding of America contribute to the post-Christian world we find ourselves in today? Is there something inherently post-Christian baked into the pie from the founding of the nation? 

In this episode, Andrew Wilson and Glen Scrivener continue their discussion of how the year 1776 has shaped our world. They trace the story forward to today, as they discuss slavery, human rights, the civil rights movement, and the sexual revolution. They talk about the apparent inevitability of progress in the 19th century and how those hopes were dashed by two world wars. 

Wilson and Scrivener also consider how these huge cultural and societal changes interact with the gospel, and conclude by discussing the extent to which Christianity cannot be forced into the neat political categories of right and left, liberal and conservative.

title: How Christianity Transformed Sex (and Therefore EVERYTHING)
description:
1900 years before the swinging sixties, there was a revolution in our attitudes toward sex and sexuality that transformed how we consider sex, marriage, family, the sexes, equality, consent, and even concepts like free will and human dignity. 

Andrew Wilson and Glen Scrivener interview Kyle Harper, Roman historian and author of "From Shame to Sin." Harper unpacks just how transformational that first revolution was, how it shaped the traditional Western understanding of sex, and how it has been challenged in the past 60 years. They also discuss ways in which sex and sexuality open a door for gospel conversations, today.

title: Christianity Does NOT Need the West (Itâ€™s the Other Way Around)
description:
How did Christianity come to shape Western culture? History is often told as the story of great men and events. But did Christianity come to shape Western culture simply as a â€œgreat ideaâ€ that carried the day? 

In this episode, Glen Scrivener and Andrew Wilson explore the role of geography, technology, and coincidence in the spread of Christianity, which has so fundamentally shaped our assumptions about the world. Geography, geology, ecology, and economics are not the topics you would usually consider in a Christian podcast, but Glen and Andrew observe how those factorsâ€”along with the fundamental goodness of the gospelâ€”combine to create an environment in which the worldview of the West was formed.

title: Check this out.
You Are WEIRD (And Itâ€™s Christianityâ€™s Fault)
description:
â€œWe hold these truths to be self-evident, that all men are created equal,â€ says the Declaration of Independence. But is it really self-evident? What is the basis of equality? How have we come to think the way we do about the world? 

Glen Scrivener and Andrew Wilson discuss the making of the Western Mind and discuss how we became WEIRD (Western, Educated, Industrialized, Rich, Democratic) as they trace the history of the West up to 1776. They make the case that far from being neutral, or self-evident, the values which many hold dear in the West today can be traced back through figures like Luther, Augustine, Paul, and ultimately to Jesus. 

They show that in spite of its secular pretensions the West remains a place thoroughly shaped and marked by a Christian worldview. So are we really post-Christian? Or is Christianity the only framework that can really make sense of the things we value most?

Originally released 18th October 2023 on The Gospel Coalition: https://youtu.be/0-TuWKmkLvw?si=fuYIh3y3okvWXePP

title: Atheists Misunderstand PASCAL'S WAGER (and so do Christians)
description:
What do Richard Dawkins, Christopher Hitchens, Alex O'Connor, Matt Dillahunty, Rationality Rules and Genetically Modified Skeptic have in common? They've all commented on Pascal's Wager. And they've all misunderstood him. It's easy to do. Most people misunderstand the French Mathematician and Philosopher (1622-1666).

In this video, Glen Scrivener discusses common misconceptions of the Wager and, with the help of Rev Dr Graham Tomlin and Tim Keller, brings out Pascal's original intention.

Graham Tomlinâ€™s book: Pascal, The Man Who Made the Modern Worldâ€¦ https://amzn.eu/d/djuoGRj

title: Easter Is For Atheists: Spoken Word
description:
Do the 321 course now, it's completely free. Sign up at http://321course.com/

Why We Made "Easter is for Atheists": https://youtu.be/b0YLZFlkQL8

WORDS//

â€œWhat would make you believe in God?â€ I asked my friend at the end of a drink,
He didnâ€™t spend a second to think,
Heâ€™d been asked before I figure,
Had his answer on a hair-trigger:

â€œIF God,â€ he said, â€œwould reconfigure the stars in the sky,Â 
to spell the 10 commandments on high,
THEN I would believe.â€

I donâ€™t know how youâ€™d conceive of divine proof,
here would you set your sights?
My friend set his to galactic heights.

But I asked: â€œWould you like this Almighty Meddler, 
shuffling nebula,
simply to tell you: â€œThou Shalt Not.â€

Back he shot:Â 
â€œI could never like God,
But if he flexed somehow,
Iâ€™d grudgingly bow.â€
I said â€œNOW we agree. We both opt out of the God that you doubt.â€Â 

But have you considered what Easterâ€™s about?

Thereâ€™s this Doubter called Thomas â€” a little like you,Â 
He too had a TEST. He said: â€œUnless I see the nail marks in his hands,
and touch the wound where the spear was rammed,
I will not believe.â€

He soon received his demand.Â 
The butchered God arose to stand,
and stretch again his hands,Â 
And say: â€œLook!Â 
See! Reach out! Believe and do not doubt!â€Â 
And Thomas knew, THIS is the FOUNT.Â 
NOW he was seeing the Source of all being,Â 
for HERE was life poured out.

He was spent for the cursed, he was parched for the thirsty.
And spilled every drop of his blood.

Of COURSE Thomas criedâ€”seeing hands and sideâ€”â€œYOU are my Lord and my God.â€

So in the end, I say to my friend: HERE is the faith-giving sightâ€”Â 
Maimed and magnificent. Wounded, omnipoten
A warrior back from the fight.

Do you have suspicions
Forget cosmic magicians;Â 
See this battle-scarred conquering Knight.

You look for God, but youâ€™ll fail to see if you raise your gaze to the stars,

Easter would teach us to lower our sights: his story he writes in the scars.

title: Molly Worthen: A Historian Converts. Interview by Glen Scrivener
description:
Glen Scrivener from Speak Life interviews Molly Worthen about her conversion to Christianity. Molly Worthen is a journalist and associate professor of history at the University of North Carolina. She is a regular contributor to publications like the New York Times, The Atlantic and The New Yorker. She's also a recent adult convert to Christianity whoâ€™s found faith in the last place she expected: A Southern Baptist Mega Church.

The Way Back is a series of interviews lighting the path back to faith. Christian author and filmmaker Glen Scrivener is speaking to a range of Christians and non-Christians about the current meaning crisis, and what we have lost in walking away from the Jesus story. In a post-Christian age, is there a way back?

Presented by Glen Scrivener
Music: 'Azlant' by Cody Martin
Edited by Thomas Thorogood

Christianity can only save Western Civilisation if it is true (Heather's article in The Critic):
https://thecritic.co.uk/christianity-can-only-save-western-civilisation-if-it-is-true/

The Way Back is a series of interviews lighting the path back to faith. Christian author and filmmaker Glen Scrivener is speaking to a range of Christians and non-Christians about the current meaning crisis, and what we have lost in walking away from the Jesus story. In a post-Christian age, is there a way back?

title: The Christmas Countdown: Magical Animation
description:
This Christmas, return to the heart of it all.
http://321course.com/

Words: Glen Scrivener
Director: Nate Morgan Locke
Music: Josh Lucas
Lead Animator: Andy Toovey
Text Animation: Timothy Last
Illustrator: Laura Sewall

Words below:

Long lay the world in bleak midwinter pining,
From Adamâ€™s fall declining,
Sorrow mining, 
hope resigning,
Yet this song to heavâ€™n inclining: 

Come, O Come, Immanuel,
And ransom captive Israel,
Descend and all our dark, dispel,
Be pleased as man with man to dwell.

This countdown to the First Noel,
They did foretell,
The prophets preached, Immanuelâ€”
â€œGod with usâ€, come to break the spell.

So lo within that manger lies, 
He who built the starry skies.
Surprise! 
Thatâ€™s GOD with us: the Royal Son,
The Second of the 3-in-1.

3 is first when counting down, 
the Father, Son and Spirit bound,
Before all things, behind, above, 
A unity: Joy, Hope and Love.

Then sent by Love and filled with Joy,
Godâ€™s Hope became a baby boy.

See him lying on a bed of straw,
The little LORD Jesus whom angels adore.
And all will surely ask: what for?

When Adamâ€™s ruin beckoned,
God sent down a 2nd.

Word of the Father, now in flesh appearingâ€”
Christ was volunteering,
Human nature commandeering.

Adamâ€™s life he would re-do.
This: the meaning of the 2.

The 2nd of the 3 became the 2nd of humanity.

And he would do it right, and bear our wrongs,
And take our curse where it belongs.
And rise again like morning sun,
And ask us all, Will you be 1?

What child is this, shares our abyss,
That we might share in all thatâ€™s his?
Made 1 with us that we might be
United for eternity.

So joy to the world, the Lord is come.
Good tidings sing in 3, 2, 1.

title: Good Men, Bad Men and "Real Men" || Nancy Pearcey, author of 'The Toxic War on Masculinity'
description:
Glen Scrivener interview's Professor Nancy Pearcey about her latest book, 'The Toxic War on Masculinity'.

If you have joined this channel as a PARTNER, you can access Glen's bonus question to Nancy plus all our other bonus content:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCJjwJMzkkVyXg3BNGUMcT0g/join

The Toxic War on Masculinity:
https://www.amazon.com/Toxic-War-Masculinity-Christianity-Reconciles/dp/0801075734

Nancy Pearcey's latest book is The Toxic War on Masculinity: How Christianity Reconciles the Sexes. Her earlier books include Love Thy Body: Answering Hard Questions about Life and Sexuality, The Soul of Science, Saving Leonardo, Finding Truth, and two ECPA Gold Medallion Award Winners: How Now Shall We Live (coauthored with Harold Fickett and Chuck Colson) and Total Truth. Her books have been translated into 19 languages. She is professor and scholar in residence at Houston Christian University. A former agnostic, Pearcey has spoken at universities such as Princeton, Stanford, USC, and Dartmouth. She has been quoted in The New Yorker and Newsweek, highlighted as one of the five top women apologists by Christianity Today, and hailed in The Economist as "America's pre-eminent evangelical Protestant female intellectual."

title: Chapter 5: Enlightenment || 'The Air We Breathe' Bible Study || With Glen Scrivener
description:
We are excited to bring you this series of videos to accompany Glen Scrivener's latest book, The Air We Breathe: How We All Came to Believe in Freedom, Kindness, Progress, and Equality

Chapter 5: Enlightenment

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS:

1. What stood out to you from this chapter?
2. How do you normally think about medieval times? Was that view challenged in this chapter?
3. The medieval period saw Christians wrestling with the right way to spread their influence: through force or persuasion? What were examples of each kind of â€œempire buildingâ€?
4. What have â€œthe Dark Agesâ€ given us?

READ EPHESIANS 6:10-20

title: I â¤ï¸ NY || New Yearâ€™s Poem for 2023 || Glen Scrivener
description:
What counts when youâ€™re counting down?
Time Square, New York
Written and performed by Glen Scrivener
Produced and edited by Thomas Thorogood
Additional New York footage from Pexels
Music: 'Longing For More' by Caleb Etheridge

WORDS //

What counts when youâ€™re counting down,
When another year comes rolling round,
When we come to town in graduation gown
For the class of â€˜22,
And now the year is through:
No refunds, and no reviews, No rewinds, and no re-dos,

And some may choose to now take stock
But nothing â€” NOTHING â€” will stop this clock. 
We didnâ€™t vote, we did not agree 
Ready or not itâ€™s 23, then 24, then 25,
If weâ€™re still alive. 
This is the game weâ€™re all born playinâ€™,
Some years youâ€™ll lose, some years youâ€™ll gain,
But nothing â€” NOTHING â€” will stop this train.

What counts when you count your days, 
from midnight? We havenâ€™t always.
The Bible starts with evening then,
At dawn, the darkâ€™s devoured again.
But these days we appraise the blaze as a phase.
And midnight to midnight frames our ways.
We begin in the dark and end in the gloom
As though the sun could be entombed.
As though the light could be consumed
And with that thinking all assume
Our onward march is surely doomed.

But what if itâ€™s gonna be alright?
What if the futureâ€™s blazing bright?
And weâ€™re headed fierce to dawning light?

What counts when we count our years?
This hereâ€™s the number to calm our fears:
Twenty Twenty Three AD, or to make a full record:
The two thousand and twenty third year of our Lord. 

What we count is HIS domain. 
The One best known for being slain,
Is One that death could not contain.
And he begins the clocks again.
Heâ€™s the driver of this train.
And nothing â€” Nothing! â€” will stop his reign.

Through the nighttime into day,
Resolute his onward way.

And so with him you need not fear:
Itâ€™s always and forever a Happy New Year.

Just make sure you tick the box to say you're a regular giver when you sign up to Discord, or pop any of the team a message in Discord if you've already joined the server before you start giving.

Our ministry is supported entirely by the generosity of people like you and we couldnâ€™t do this work without your prayers and support. Thank you so much for your interest in our work. title: Should We Be Worried About the 2021 Census Christianity Data? || Speak Life Reacts
description:

The percentage of people who said they are Christian has fallen from 59.3% in 2011 to 46.2%. Should we be worried? Glen Scrivener from Speak Life takes a look at the 2021 census religion data.

title: Shelter from the Storm || Sermon by Glen Scrivener || Luke 6:46-49
description:
This sermon was preached by Glen Scrivener at All Souls Church, Eastbourne on 19 September 2021.

More sermons by Glen: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL8dvLpalib_zkRNlr5TtnFAeP1yNLt38-

Glen's *adapted* lyrics to Shelter From The Storm:

'Twas in another lifetime, He joined our race of mud
When blackness was a virtue, His road was paved with blood
He came into our wilderness, and took our broken form.
"Come in," He said, "I'll give you shelter from the storm."

When He passed this way He said, â€œyou can rest assured
I've come to take your heavy load, on that I give my wordâ€
In a world of steel-eyed death, and men who are fighting to be warm.
"Come in," He said, "I'll give you shelter from the storm."

I had never paid Him mind, never given heed
Took my life and fed it to my lust and hate and greed
Every day was dirty since the day that I was born
"Come in," He said, "I'll give you shelter from the storm."

I put my heart to weary strain, loved the things that rust
Kissed the lips of strangers that crumbled into dust
Lived in darkness, death and fear, hopeless and forlorn
"Come in" He said "I'll give you shelter from the storm." 

I was burned out from exhaustion, buried in the hail,
Poisoned in the bushes and blown out on the trail,
Frantic as I grasped and groped until my heart was torn 
"Come in," He said, "I'll give you shelter from the storm."

In a little hilltop gathering, they gambled for His clothes
He came to bring salvation, gave Himself a lethal dose.
He offered up His innocence and got repaid with scorn.
"Come in," He said, "I'll give you shelter from the storm."

Suddenly I turned around and He was hangin' there
Dressed in blood and nails and tears and every worldly care
He spread his arms to every soul and took their crown of thorns.
"Come in," He said, "I'll give you shelter from the storm."

But death could never hold him, He shook it off with ease
And preached to all us mortal men that deathly cares should cease
A whole new world of life and hope began that emâ€™rald morn 
"Come in" He said, "I'll give you shelter from the storm."

Now the wall between us, is broken down to dust
He stands above the shattered ruins, wondering if we'll trust
In Him who came to cross and crown before was even born
"Come in," He says, "I'll give you shelter from the storm."

I've heard newborn babies cry like a mourning dove
And old men with broken teeth stranded without love.
But He clutched our heavy songs and fused them to His broken form.
"Come in," He says, "I'll give you shelter from the storm."

The future stretches hungry into the waking world
Where every tear is wiped away. Eternity unfurled!
And He will call the age to be on that exquisite dawn
"Come in" He says "I'll give you shelter from the storm."

----

title: Easter Uprising || The Weekend That Made Our World || Trigger Warning: Historical violence described
description:
Trigger Warning: The violence and abuse of the Classical world is mentioned

In this short documentary we travel from London to Rome and back again in search of a true appreciation for the cross. From the air conditioned halls of the National Gallery to the brutal exhibits of the Colosseum we chart the way the crucifixion has been understood. What we discover is that the way we see the cross has been transformed, largely because the cross has transformed the way we see. Two thousand years ago a revolution was unleashed â€” a revolution we still live within. Watch as Glen Scrivener investigates the Easter Uprising which has rocked our world.

title: Is The Future Post-Christian or Post-Secular? || Ukraine, War, Plague, Famine, and Belief
description:
The secularization thesis was the theory that the world is destined to get less religious as prosperity grows across the world. The thesis is looking increasingly like a myth. The world is becoming far more religious and Christianity remains the largest worldview globally. As we face war, plague and economic hardship, many are turning to a spirituality many had assumed was destined to die out. How should the church relate to this moment?

Nate Morgan Locke, Paul Feesey and Glen Scrivener discuss.

title: Christians React To Russian Invasion Of Ukraine
description: On tonight's Speakeasy, Glen, Nate & Paul talk about the events that have unfolded in Ukraine over the last week.

description:

title: The Meaning of January 6th || Epiphany, The Capitol and Symbolism || SpeakEasy
description: It's Epiphany â€” a word that means 'appearance' or 'manifestation.' In the church calendar it's a time to remember the appearance of Christ to those eastern magician-astrologers, the Magi (Matthew 2:1-12). Incidentally it was on this day last year that the Capitol in Washington DC was overrun. What kind of 'appearance' was that, and how does it relate to the appearance of Christ? Nate Morgan Locke and Glen Scrivener discuss!

title: Speak Life || Looking Forward, Looking Back
description:
After 2020, we thought things could not go any lower. Then came 2021. There was the pandemic. And beyond Covid, there were other forces going viral â€” like tribalism and divisions (see this brilliant interview with Paul Blackham: https://youtu.be/RoAZ7zznkKw).

2021 was also the year we grappled with terrible evil in our midst. At Speak Life we spoke to insiders at Ravi Zacharias International Ministries like Sam Allberry (https://youtu.be/SMA6ZDS7eLc), outsiders breaking the story like Steve Baughman (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pv4L8k1hs2A). We spoke to survivors like Lori Anne Thompson (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oHUU-nVKT-0), and we spoke to healers like Diane Langberg (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jvIpQnBpNWU). There are eleven videos in our Church Abuse Playlist (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SuOoXZ6RSPg&list=PL4zD5797LHdeSKbVtM7_AzOO-4miUyRQo). Please watch because this issue is not going away, and we need to continue to shine a light here.

2021 was also difficult for personal reasons. Our own Paul Feesey spent 3 months in hospital with his one year old daughter who came close to death many times. Paul talking of the sustaining grace of Jesus has been one of the highlights of this year: https://youtu.be/yPIvVA43yZk

This year has also seen great growth as experienced evangelist and filmmaker Nate Morgan Locke has joined us on the team: https://youtu.be/lOz6GU-1ARE

Nate has helped us get ready for our third year of the Foundry. With creative evangelists coming from England, Ireland, Scotland, Wales and the US, itâ€™s been our biggest yet. Weâ€™ve also invited people here for our intensive weeks of training where people from all over the country meet the team, catch the vision and learn the craft. And weâ€™ve had regular Friday intensives where we study Scripture, Culture, Creativity and Mission.

Throughout it all weâ€™ve been producing our regular weekly broadcasts as well as our seasonal short films: 

Cancel Valentines: https://youtu.be/1A1QGrnedlQ

Best Dad: https://youtu.be/JMBl7bzKBtw

Mr Thankful: https://youtu.be/lXYy4W5wAfM

Christmouse: https://youtu.be/g0bYPt8Upzo

The Night Before Christmas: https://youtu.be/6OHYB4bQNl4

We've made over a hundred videos, with over a million views. Ten million minutes of gospel proclamation have been watched on YouTube alone. Then there's our impact on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, TikTok, podcasting, face to face and in the ongoing discipleship of young evangelists.

Next year, watch out for a fresh look coming to Speak Life: an all new website; the refilming of 321 our evangelistic presentation; a new bookâ€”The Air We Breatheâ€”and a new intake of trainee evangelists. But hereâ€™s what wonâ€™t change, we will keep on lifting up the name of Jesus however we can to resource the church and reach the world.

Will you help us?

We cannot do this alone. We have a faithful band of supporters who keep the work afloat here at Speak Life â€” we are so grateful for them â€” but they need brothers and sisters alongside them. If youâ€™ve benefited from Speak Life why not consider us a missionary organisation that you support. You give to your local church, perhaps you give to a missionary overseas, would you please consider supporting us as a growing Christian ministry in great need of your prayers and your financial help. All we do is down to the generosity of people just like you. Join the happy band of supporters at speaklife.org.uk/give.

So whoever you are and whatever kind of year you have had, I pray you know the blessings of Immanuel right here in the midst of this dark valley, and the hope of the dawning light that has broken upon this world. From the whole Speak Life team, we wish you a very merry Christmas and a Happy New Year!

title: The Life and Legacy of Sir David Amess (And The Blame Games That Followed) || 18 October 2021
description:
The tragic death of Sir David Amess MP last week triggered a number of "hot takes" from journalists and politicians. Many factors have been blamed including social media and heightened political rhetoric. What do we learn from these attempts to find a root cause? And what do we learn from examining the life of Sir David himself? Such lessons might not be the ones our political commentators have promoted.

Nate Morgan Locke and Glen Scrivener chat through the issues of the day on Mondays at 8pm (GMT+1). Join us live to add your voice, and check out more at speaklife.org.uk

title: Identity Politics: Are Evangelicals to Blame? || SpeakEasy 11 October 2021
description:
Tonight on the SpeakEasy, Glen Scrivener and Nate Morgan Locke discuss the prevalence of expressive individualism. Modern people focus on ourselves, our journeys, our identities. We minimise the influence of history, family, culture, institutionsâ€”even biology. Instead we spotlight our personal experience and individual choices. But why?

The turn towards the self took a decisive step in 1517 and evangelicals have been treading the path ever since. Are we to blame for this massive emphasis on "identity"?

title: What Can We Learn from Mars Hill || Interview with Liam Thatcher
description:
The Rise and Fall of Mars Hill has been a fascinating podcast-documentary about Mark Driscoll and Mars Hill Church in Seattle. Recently Liam Thatcher blogged about its brilliance, its significance and our challenges in receiving it rightly. The article has been hugely popular as well as receiving good natured pushback. Here Glen Scrivener and Nate Morgan Locke discuss the podcast, its reception (especially on Twitter) and what we can learn from both the catastrophe at Mars Hill as well as this kind of journalism.

title: "We are called to participate in God" || Jonathan Pageau on the Inescapability of the Jesus Story
description:
Watch the full discussion: https://youtu.be/EvJb_QX9Atk

In this interview, Glen Scrivener talks to Jonathan Pageau. Jonathan is an icon carver, editor of the Orthodox Arts Journal and a public speaker. Through his YouTube channel, he regularly explores symbolism and the meaning crisis. Here, Glen and Jonathan discuss symbolism in the book of Genesis, and why we often miss it.

Jonathan Pageau's ( @Jonathan Pageau ) YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/JonathanPageau

#JonathanPageau

RESET is a series of conversations exploring the meaning crisis. With the help of cultural analysts and biblical scholars we're going back to the beginning â€” to Genesis, the West's great origins story â€” to hear the ancient texts speaking today.

Glen Scrivener is an ordained church minister and filmmaker. In this series he asks questions about conflict, suffering, death, sex, equality, science, and what it means to be human. This is the 19th interview in the RESET series: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL4zD5797LHdfS5-U6lPPvofTph6lvJRrD

title: The Richness of the Bible || Interview With Matt Searles, Author of 'God's Story'
description:
Glen speaks to Matt Searles, Director of Training in the South Central Gospel Partnership. Matt is a musician and loves teaching from the Psalms. His books include 'Tumbling Sky - Psalm devotions for weary souls'. In this conversation, Glen asks Matt about his recent book 'God's Story: The Bible Explained', an accessible and creatively presented Bible overview. They discuss the richness and interconnectedness of God's word, and what it means to see Christ in all of scripture.

title: What is Matt Hancock guilty of? Adultery? Hypocrisy? Anything? || LIVEcast 28th June 2021
description:
On this episode of the LIVEcast, Glen talks about the resignation of Matt Hancock, the former Health Secretary for the British government. He resigned after being caught on CCTV kissing one of his aides, who isn't his wife. But the outcry has been over the breaking of social distancing rules which he helped to make, rather than his marriage vows. So we ask: what is he guilty of? Adultery? Hypocrisy? Anything?

title: Best Dad || A Father's Day Short Film
description:
Happy Father's Day! Watch our explainer video here:  https://youtu.be/vosjum7m9gc

We hope our new short film BEST DAD will put a smile on your face and give you something to think about.

The story is set on Father's Day and involves three generations of men from the same family. By the end we see that that love means paying attention, what we consume will consume us, and with the very Best Dad, there is a way of breaking the chains and being the parent we ought to be.

We really hope you will watch, like and share this two and a half minute comedy. You can download it here for use in churches or similar: https://speaklife.org.uk/2021/06/18/best-dad-our-new-short-comedy

And our Behind The Sofa video goes further into the story behind the film and the Dad above all dads.

title: Richard Dawkins & Brendan O'Connor: The Rights, the Wrongs and What We All Assume | LIVEcast 25 May
description:
Recently Richard Dawkins went on Brendan O'Connor's radio show on RTE, Ireland. https://www.rte.ie/radio1/brendan-oco...

The 20 minute interview has become famous for the way the conversation developed towards the end. But here Glen Scrivener and Paul Feesey discuss the entirety of the conversation which ranged over some fascinating terrain.

They discuss the assumptions behind Richard Dawkins' now infamous "Abort it and try again" statement from 2014 and the way so much discussion of the controversy misses vital points.

title: Oppression Means Opportunity || Interview with Cedo Ralevic || Gospel Preaching In Tito's Yugoslavia
description:
ÄŒedo RaleviÄ‡ was born in 1949 in Kosovo and Metohija. He was born in a communist country, under Tito's rule (who died in 1980). 

In the year 1964 ÄŒedo became a Christian in 1964 through the witness of his older brother, Simo. He was baptized in 1967 in Novi Sad. From September 1970 until 1974 ÄŒedo studied theology in Novi Sad, North Serbia. After finishing his studies he became a pastor in a small place in Macedonia. He returned to Serbia in October 1980, moving to NiÅ¡ with his family, and he began a mission work of planting churches and spreading the Gospel all over South of Serbia. 

ÄŒedo remains in NiÅ¡ where today there are many more churches. Together with his brother Simo and son Emanuel, he founded Balkan Theological Seminary in 2013 which seeks to raise up many more gospel ministers for Serbia and beyond.

title: What is sex for? || Purposeful Sexuality || An interview with Ed Shaw
description:
There is one question we never ask: What is sex for? 

Glen talks to Ed Shaw, Pastor of Emmanuel City Centre in Bristol and co-founder of Living Out. They are an organisation committed to seeing Christians living out their sexuality and identity in ways that enable all to flourish in Christ-like faithfulness. As a same sex attracted Christian, Ed encourages us to look beyond just seeking fulfillment in heterosexual marriage alone or embracing a lifestyle and identity that goes against scripture. He encourages us to embrace the better story the bible tells us about sexuality.

Ed Shaw's new book, Purposeful Sexuality, can be found here: https://ivpbooks.com/purposeful-sexuality

title: Are All Lives Equally Valuable? || Lord Sumption and Piers Morgan are BOTH wrong.
description:
We have a deep sense of the equal value of all people no matter their age, sex, race, creed, etc. But where has this come from? And what does it mean about the difficult decisions we have to make when rationing scarce resources?

Recently Lord Jonathan Sumption sparked a controversy on the BBC1 programme, The Big Questions, by saying that not all lives are equally valuable. The controversy is testimony to his unfortunate language but also to the deeply ingrained Christian sentiments we still share in the West. But when Piers Morgan tries to call out Sumption it turns out he digs a pit then falls into it.

We speak far more about the originals of human rights and equality in our RESET series. See in particular this episode: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ODhbpUFPLq0&list=PL4zD5797LHdfMAdMokPT9wtUl5TxJ5_np&index=22

RESET is a series of 16 INTERVIEWS and 7 EPISODES exploring the meaning crisis. With the help of cultural analysts and biblical scholars we're going back to the beginning â€” to Genesis, the West's great origins story â€” to hear the ancient texts speaking today.

In this episode, Glen Scrivener and Paul Feesey look at the so-called "death of God" and ask the question â€” if the west walks away from its Christian roots, what's meaning, what's morality and what's missing?

EPISODES (Released each day between 26 Dec 2020 and 1 Jan 2021):

Episode 1: What's Meaning, What's Morality, What's Missing?
Episode 2: Human Rights, Human Equality, and Humanism.
Episode 3: Conflict, Suffering, and Death.
Episode 4: Relationships, Sex, and the Body.
Episode 5: Science, Rationality, and Consciousness.
Episode 6: Story, Truth and Beauty.
Episode 7: The Heavens, the Earth, and God.

title: Christmas in Dark Places 2020 || Christmas Poem
description:
If you want to download this for your church services or events, please visit www.speaklife.org.uk/christmas

It used to be summer when Christmas came round,
Neath tall southern skies, over sun-scorched ground,
With the backyard cricket, the barbies, the beach,
And munching on mangoes to watch the Queenâ€™s Speech.
The slatherings of sunscreen, the glorious glare
And toasting the glow in the warm evening air.

It used to be summer, when I was young.
A golden age in a land far flung.
But there came a point, I crossed a divide,
Went up in the world and summer had died.
December is dark now, the nights close in,
So we huddle together as kith and as kin.

Itâ€™s winter now when Christmas rolls round,
We celebrate still though with different surrounds.
We mull the wine and strike the matches,
Light the fires, batten the hatches,
Gather around the warming beam
Of family love or a TV screen.
So safe inside, no place to go,
We toast marshmallows and let it snow.

Our summerâ€™s gone, if youâ€™ve been around,
youâ€™ve felt the fall: lifeâ€™s run aground.
Weâ€™ve gone up in the world, seen summer die.
So whatâ€™s our hope? The dark defy?
Stoke the hearth? Retreat indoors?
Rug up warm with you and yours?
The shadow reaches even here,
But THIS is the place for Christmas cheer.

Itâ€™s dark, in the bible, when Christmas is spoken.
Always a bolt from the blue for the broken.
Itâ€™s the valley of shadow, the land of the dead,
Itâ€™s, â€œNo place in the inn,â€ so He stoops to the shed.
Heâ€™s born to the shameful, bends to the weak,
becomes the lowly: the God who canâ€™t speak!
And yet, what a Word, this Saviour who comes,
Our dismal, abysmal depths He plumbs.
Through crib and then cross, to compass our life.
To carry and conquer. Our Brother in strife.
He became what we are: our failures He shouldered,
To bring us to His life: forever enfolded.
He took on our frailty, He took on all-comers,
To turn all our winters to glorious summers.

Itâ€™s Christmas now, whatever the weather,
Some soak in the sun, some huddle together.
But fair days or foul, our plight He embraces.
Real Christmas shines in the darkest of places

title: The Coming by R.S. Thomas || Spectacular Christmas Poem Animated
description:
The Coming is an advent poem by R.S. Thomas. Here it is brought to life by animator Rod March and voiced by Barry Cooper.

To discover more about Christmas, get your free book from speaklife.org.uk/the-gift

WORDS:

And God held in his hand
A small globe.  Look he said.
The son looked.  Far off,
As through water, he saw
A scorched land of fierce
Colour.  The light burned
There; crusted buildings
Cast their shadows: a bright
Serpent, A river
Uncoiled itself, radiant
With slime.
               On a bare
Hill a bare tree saddened
The sky.  many People
Held out their thin arms
To it, as though waiting
For a vanished April
To return to its crossed
Boughs.  The son watched
Them.  Let me go there, he said.

title: "It's Not Natural" || Science, Sentience, Sex and How It All Fits Together  || LIVEcast 16 Nov 2020
description:
In the news we hear about the destructive power of nature â€” a pandemic â€” as well as the life-saving potential of science â€” a vaccine. 

But what is nature? What is the place of humanity in it? How should we steward it? When science allows us to manipulate it, even to manipulate humans, what should be our response? And if Christians make the case for something being "natural" or "against nature", what do they mean?

As ever, Glen Scrivener and Paul Feesey discuss, with the help of live commenters. Join us on Mondays at 1pm to add your own wisdom.

title: Facing Up to Death || John Behr | RESET
description:

title: Acts 4: Courage In Fractured Times
description:
Glen Scrivener preached this sermon for Redeemer Church in Delhi, India on 26th July 2020. The passage is Acts 4:1-22.

1 The priests and the captain of the temple guard and the Sadducees came up to Peter and John while they were speaking to the people. 2 They were greatly disturbed because the apostles were teaching the people, proclaiming in Jesus the resurrection of the dead. 3 They seized Peter and John and, because it was evening, they put them in jail until the next day. 4 But many who heard the message believed; so the number of men who believed grew to about five thousand.

5 The next day the rulers, the elders and the teachers of the law met in Jerusalem. 6 Annas the high priest was there, and so were Caiaphas, John, Alexander and others of the high priestâ€™s family. 7 They had Peter and John brought before them and began to question them: â€œBy what power or what name did you do this?â€

8 Then Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit, said to them: â€œRulers and elders of the people! 9 If we are being called to account today for an act of kindness shown to a man who was lame and are being asked how he was healed, 10 then know this, you and all the people of Israel: It is by the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, whom you crucified but whom God raised from the dead, that this man stands before you healed. 11 Jesus is

â€œâ€˜the stone you builders rejected,
    which has become the cornerstone.â€™

12 Salvation is found in no one else, for there is no other name under heaven given to mankind by which we must be saved.â€

13 When they saw the courage of Peter and John and realized that they were unschooled, ordinary men, they were astonished and they took note that these men had been with Jesus. 14 But since they could see the man who had been healed standing there with them, there was nothing they could say. 15 So they ordered them to withdraw from the Sanhedrin and then conferred together. 16 â€œWhat are we going to do with these men?â€ they asked. â€œEveryone living in Jerusalem knows they have performed a notable sign, and we cannot deny it. 17 But to stop this thing from spreading any further among the people, we must warn them to speak no longer to anyone in this name.â€

18 Then they called them in again and commanded them not to speak or teach at all in the name of Jesus. 19 But Peter and John replied, â€œWhich is right in Godâ€™s eyes: to listen to you, or to him? You be the judges! 20 As for us, we cannot help speaking about what we have seen and heard.â€

21 After further threats they let them go. They could not decide how to punish them, because all the people were praising God for what had happened. 22 For the man who was miraculously healed was over forty years old.

title: We Have a Lamb
description:
We Have A Lamb began life as a meditation on Revelation 7:17. It then became a poem which was picked up by The Gospel Coalition. Phil Moore saw it and put a fantastic tune to it. Then David Gibson arranged it for strings and singers, and we got to work recruiting musicians and singers. Finally, Kezia Hulse added some charming animations, and Max Paterson made the video. This is the result:

Feel free to use this in your Sunday services / streams (CCLI number: 7154491). We encourage churches to download the video file and cut it into your Sunday streams and we encourage every Christian to share it among friends on social media. Find the video file and sheet music at speaklife.org.uk/lamb


LYRICS

For mistakes we canâ€™t forget
and the sins that still besetâ€¦
We have a Lamb.

For our fraught and anxious realm,
for the fears that overwhelmâ€¦
We have a throne.

We sing worthy, worthy is the Lamb
Who was slain for the world â€”
Royal arms unfurled.
We sing glory, glory to the Christ:
Your cross â€” our Fountain of Life.

For our lost and lonely hearts,
for our gnarled and tangled pathsâ€¦
We have a Shepherd.

For our dry and listless souls
and our thirst for being wholeâ€¦
We have a Stream.

We sing worthy, worthy is the Lamb
Who was slain for the world â€”
Royal arms unfurled.
We sing glory, glory to the Christ:
Your cross â€” our Fountain of Life.

For regret and ravaged years,
for all sweet and bitter tears...
We have a Father.

For our treks through burning sands,
To our home in promised lands,
This hope till all is done:
Our God the three-in-one.

We sing worthy, worthy is the Lamb
Who was slain for the world â€”
Royal arms unfurled.
We sing glory, glory to the Christ:
Your cross â€” our Fountain of Life.

title: Highest Death Toll During Corona || Numbers || Poem
description:
Numbers. 
Thatâ€™s what we get, each day weâ€™re beset
with numbers. 

Numbers doing what numbers do,
Numbing the me, numbing the you,
Numbing our sense of the she and the he,
Numbing the sense that THEY are me.
With numbers â€˜Theyâ€™ stay â€˜THEYâ€™, 
Itâ€™s what numbers have allowed.
Each life lost is lost in the crowd.

The shroud of death enfolds the heap,
Costs it cheap. We try to weep but numbers can put us all to sleep.

Except for those who we have known,
Our flesh and blood, our very own,
Who, when exhaling final groans, heard our goodbyes on the phone.
And then were buried all alone.

How can each loss be shown?

Each mum, each son, each dad, each wife,
Each irreplaceable, iridescent life. 
Each gift a vast amount.
Each ONE too much to count.

Beware the numbers, our dose each day,
Until weâ€™re numbered all away. 
Until weâ€™re deadened to the toll,
Till each oneâ€™s lost into the whole.

But no. Awake my soul. 
Make each figure strike,
Like spurs in my flesh, to stir me afresh,
To see galactic worth distilled in each daughter of earth, 
in each son brought to birth,
And near infinite crime in snuffing them out. 
Let me shout to the skies with full-throated cries, 
and, desperateâ€”despiseâ€”when the least of them dies. 

And when COVID is done, 
May the numbers not numb
May we wake from our slumber
And number each one.

Because some day soon you will hear 
that the peak is long past and weâ€™ve got the All Clear.
The lockdown has lifted and friends can draw near. 
And we will cheer. 
But letâ€™s be clear,
The numbers are not 
what they appear. 

Each year, in this land, understand we have FOUR Covids.
In This Nation, 200 000 terminations.
A four-fold pestilence devours these isles, the dead in piles, a hideous mount.
But do THEY count?

In heavenâ€™s account but what will WE say?
Each day, 550 slain. They are Abel. We are Cain. 
And righteous blood cries out in vain. 

It does not enter our calculation. We deem it beneath our briefing the nation. We only make public explanation of THESE when disEASE is pursuing. But not when the deaths are All OUR doing. 

And maybe you say, â€œIt doesnâ€™t compare.â€ 
I say: Thatâ€™s fair.

Cos with the virus we were afflicted, this black death is self-inflicted.
Are you convicted?

Iâ€™ll depict another figure, this oneâ€™s bigger. 
As I bring this number, I hear you numbing, You are. Youâ€™re ahhing and umming,
Youâ€™re drumming your fingers. Your mind is elsewhere. There you go with that thousand yard stare.
Are you there?

By June, worldwide, half a million have died of COVID. As Iâ€™ve said, each ONE dead is plenty. But if weâ€™re counting in millions, abortionâ€™s killed 20. And thatâ€™s just by June.

Itâ€™s not stopping any time soon.
Every four days it kills more than the virus. 
Let this truth fire us: in 96 hours it devours just the same. But without the fame. 
This, friend, is our silent shame. 

So awake my soul. Make each figure strike,
Like spurs in my flesh, to stir me afresh,
To see galactic worth distilled in each daughter of earth, 
in each son meant for birth.
And near infinite crime in snuffing them out. 
Let me shout to the skies with full-throated cries, andâ€”desperateâ€”despise, when the least of them dies. 

And when COVID is done, 
May the numbers not numb
May we wake from our slumber
And number each one.


Glen Scrivener is an Australian author and speaker living in the UK.

title: Great Question || Glen Scrivener Answers 10 Thorny Questions About Christianity
description:
For a louder version of the same video go here: https://youtu.be/ExnQDbfFiGU 

Andrew Baughen of Reality Church, London poses Glen Scrivener questions about the faith gathered from many enquirers.

1. Is the God that Jews and Muslims believe in the same as the Christian God?

2. Is it possible to be a Christian and believe in evolution?

3. What would you have said to Charles Darwin?

4. Is the whole of scripture relevant today? 

5. How can we trust that the entire Bible was breathed out by God?

6. Why would God allow the Coronavirus? 

7. How should we think about all the different denominations of Christianity?

8. Should we pray to "Our Father...", or Jesus or the Holy Spirit, or...? 

9. How do you pray?

10. Especially during lockdown married relationships are under strain. What help does Christianity give to maintaining good relationships. 

Follow Reality Church London on Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/realitychurchlondon/

title: Easter Spoken word | Authored to die
description:
Words by Benjamin Holmes

The story of all stories
Written into nature
Obscured by the furniture
Lies a story unable to be deleted from the history books
But no villain can kill
Itâ€™s echoing still
We write our own path within the parameters,Â 
And we wrote in death, disease and the need for the ambulance
Placed, purposely for perfection
Mankind chose negation rather than to live as designed creation
Through disobedience and rejection, and sullen introspection
Weâ€™ve turned from light and life,Â 
Weâ€™ve chosen fire and strife,
No longer able to dwell with brightness
Like sheep gone astray weâ€™ve turned from Godâ€™s way
Weâ€™ve gone off script - created our own devilish ditch

ButÂ  Â  the    Author

He wrote Himself in when He could have written off humanityÂ 
Like a root out of dry ground, a tender shoot He grew up
One mission in His mind to save mankindÂ 
All who are weary, abandoned, despised,
Broken, neglected, hard done by and hopeless
These are the characters Christ had in focus
All who admit to their faults and come humbly
He swoops down from heaven and aims for that one tree

Up the hillÂ 
Too weak to carry His own cross
Too meek to ascend to heaven without gathering the lost
The carpenterâ€™s hands outstretched to the world He once carved
His body now starvedÂ 
Disfigured and dying the Maker pinned down who had hung up the earthâ€¦now crying
We had no time and made no place but He stepped into time and space to take my place, the place that was meant to be mine to face

Broken, mangled, swollen
The ultimate image bearer beaten so badly the image just bears pain with eternal scars
But these wounds are from love, healing our wound when we fell from aboveÂ 
The author of life, is now authored to die,Â 
He met us who failed and entered our tale - accepted the thorns and the spear and the nails
He knew how it ended yet still he expended His life like a lamb that was slain

He shouldered the pain as the Father pressed down, that crown of thorns and sin of the world crushed him as he became an offering for sin
He authored this worldâ€™s laws yet put His glory on pauseÂ 
to die for the sinners cause
The sinners who pierced Him


And then..
He ascends, his labours now finished his sacrifice crownedÂ 
The lamb on the throne as the credits roll down


The tale untwisted, the story rewritten
The author turned Hero, to do what we didnâ€™t
To do what we couldnâ€™t, to undo the curse.
Those arms nailed wide span the universe

Stretching beyond all the forces that scatter,Â 
written in scars forever
â€˜You matterâ€™

The Hero who dies and rises in glory
The author of life rewriting the story

Important comments:

0:01 Can we use a recording made by someone else?:
Any artist can be contacted to ask if we can use their mp3, lyrics or videos in our stream.
A couple of big names have released blanket statements already so we donâ€™t need to ask them.
Getty Music:
https://www.gettymusic.com/streaminginfo shows they give permission for use of mp3, videos and lyrics
https://www.gettymusic.com/videosandmusicresources Gettys have released a catalogue of lyric videos available for free download, other songs we would need to buy the mp3
Sovereign Grace:
https://sovereigngracemusic.org/2020/03/live-stream-update/ permission given for all their mp3, video and lyrics to be streamed. You would still need to buy the mp3 tracks or use their YouTube videos for free, but their videos can't be downloaded like the gettys can. They also ask churches â€œto include the copyright information either in your video, in the video notes, or on your website, including the phrase, â€œUsed by permission,â€ after the phrase, â€œAll rights reserved.â€â€
https://sovereigngracemusic.org/music/videos/ video library
https://sovereigngracemusic.org/music/songs/ full song library
Emu Music:
https://www.facebook.com/.../a.1015.../10158001070351113/... consent given to use any of their songs and lyrics, including for their youtube lyrics videos. They ask that we display copyright info in the video description. A very few free lyric videos to download, otherwise weâ€™d have to buy the tracks.
https://emumusic.com/products/downloadable-lyric-videos... free lyric videos
https://emumusic.com/pages/song-index-h index of all songs
This won't necessarily stop the robots from flagging these songs, so test, test, test.

title: The Coming â€” A Christmas Poem
description:
In this cinematic journey we explore R.S. Thomas's incredible Christmas poem, The Coming.

For more Christmas films and other resources, see speaklife.org.uk/Christmas 

And God held in his hand
A small globe. Look he said.
The son looked. Far off,
As through water, he saw
A scorched land of fierce
Colour. The light burned
There; crusted buildings
Cast their shadows: a bright
Serpent, a river
Uncoiled itself, radiant
With slime.
                        On a bare
Hill a bare tree saddened
The sky. Many People
Held out their thin arms
To it, as though waiting
For a vanished April
To return to its crossed
Boughs. The son watched
Them. Let me go there, he said.

title: There's a Dragon in my Nativity
description:
There is a big, red, scary dragon in my nativity.  The wise men are trembling.  There is no room for such a monstrous beast at the inn.  This is the TRUE story of the dragon at Christmas. #ComeAtMeJohnLewis #ComeAtMeWaitrose #Christmas
Don't worry, there is a happy ending.

Speaklife is a UK based charity that resources the church to reach the world.Â  To learn more about us visit:Â https://speaklife.org.uk/

To learn more about the dragon in my nativity visit:Â http://speaklife.org.uk/dragon/

Facebook:Â https://www.facebook.com/SpeakLifeUK/
Twitter: @speaklifeUK
Instagram: @speaklifeUK 

Thereâ€™s a dragon in my nativity,
Dreadful and immense,
The shepherds quake, the wise men shake
And spill their frankincense.

The cattle are a-lowing and
The baby is awake,
While Joe and Mary tremble,
â€œOh! This must be some mistake!â€™

Thereâ€™s a dragon over Bethlehem,
I donâ€™t know how he came.
I didnâ€™t think a donkey
Could have borne the dragonâ€™s frame.

I donâ€™t believe the census, 
Had been called for such as him.
And Iâ€™m certain that when Dragon knocked,
No room was at the Inn.

Thereâ€™s a dragon by the stable, 
I donâ€™t know why heâ€™s there. 
He hasnâ€™t brought a present
And he only seems to glare. 

He hovers over Davidâ€™s town,
That still beneath him lies.
Yet no-oneâ€™s sleep is dreamless,
Underneath his piercing eyes. 

This dragon isnâ€™t visible 
With ordinary sight.
You cannot snap a selfie,
Or televise his flight.

Unseen, he stands for every power 
that stands against the earth,
The death, disease and darkness
Overshadowing each birth.

This dragon is an enemy
Of all thatâ€™s good and true.
This monster lies and steals and kills â€”
Heâ€™s coming after you.

Above each crib the dragon hovers,
Sure to swallow whole,
Rulers, empires, beauty, joy â€”
A flesh-and-blood black hole.

But dragons always meet their match,
They always meet their doom.
A hero rises to the fight,
To cast them into gloom.

And so at this nativity,
Arose another player.
The baby wrapped in swaddling cloths â€”
He was a dragon slayer.

Heâ€™d come to fight through Herodâ€™s plot,
Through dangers big and small.
He took on evil, sickness, death, 
And triumphed over all.

A dragon or a baby â€”
Just who would win the fight? 
It wasnâ€™t really fair, you see,
The Child was a Knight.

From high above and long before, 
He knew what must be done.
He knew the dragon waiting here,
And still he chose to come.

Thereâ€™s a dragon in my nativity,
A fierce and monstrous danger.
But fiercer still the bravery
And love within the manger.

title: The Happyland Nativity: The Meaning of Christmas
description:
Speak Life and Hope Together have recreated the Nativity scene, a summary of the birth of Jesus, with characters from the Happyland nativity set in a stop motion video. This short story comes directly from the Bible to tell the true meaning of the Christmas holiday.Â Follow with Mary, Joseph, the angels, and sheep as they travel through a quirky animated adventure.

Luke chapter 2:
In those days Caesar Augustus issued a decree that a census should be taken of the entire Roman world. (This was the first census that took place while Quirinius was governor of Syria.) And everyone went to their own town to register. So Joseph also went up from the town of Nazareth in Galilee to Judea, to Bethlehem the town of David, because he belonged to the house and line of David.  He went there to register with Mary, who was pledged to be married to him and was expecting a child. While they were there, the time came for the baby to be born, and she gave birth to her firstborn, a son. She wrapped him in cloths and placed him in a manger, because there was no guest room available for them. And there were shepherds living out in the fields nearby, keeping watch over their flocks at night. An angel of the Lord appeared to them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they were terrified. But the angel said to them, â€œDo not be afraid. I bring you good news that will cause great joy for all the people. Today in the town of David a Savior has been born to you; he is the Messiah, the Lord. This will be a sign to you: You will find a baby wrapped in cloths and lying in a manger.â€ Suddenly a great company of the heavenly host appeared with the angel, praising God and saying,
 â€œGlory to God in the highest heaven,
    and on earth peace to those on whom his favor rests.â€
 When the angels had left them and gone into heaven, the shepherds said to one another, â€œLetâ€™s go to Bethlehem and see this thing that has happened, which the Lord has told us about.â€
 So they hurried off and found Mary and Joseph, and the baby, who was lying in the manger.  When they had seen him, they spread the word concerning what had been told them about this child, and all who heard it were amazed at what the shepherds said to them. But Mary treasured up all these things and pondered them in her heart. The shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all the things they had heard and seen, which were just as they had been told.

title: Is Religion Harmful? Glen Scrivener answers
description:
Imagine a sceptical feminist who hates the institution of marriage. Now imagine that she falls in love and even ends up marrying the guy. That is how Glen Scrivener feels about institutional religion. He has always been sceptical, but he's met a guy and this guy has converted him. 

It's not that Christians love the institution of religion (any more than the woman loves the institution of marriage). We love Jesus. And on the inside of a relationship with Jesus we have seen that some of our scepticism was warranted and some of it wasn't. But Jesus himself makes all the difference.

Recently Jordan Peterson was interviewed by Dennis Prager (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L47oJxwp6yg). Peterson told Prager he didn't want to claim to believe in God because who could bear such a burden? Esther O'Reilly wrote an incisive article explaining that faith is not a burden. title: Valentines Love Poem - BeLoved
description:
Itâ€™s the fairy tale we all believe in â€“ connection, completion, love without parting. The merest glimpse of it captures our hearts. But is the fairy tale real? Is there such a thing as endless bliss, unconquered love and a happily ever after?

Countless failed relationships and a beckoning grave cry out No. Love does not seem to have the last word in our lives â€“ decay, disease, divorce, depression and death does. Can we really believe in love?

The answer is Yes, but only because there is a love despite our deserving, a love stronger than death, a love beyond this world. Jesus makes the fairy tale true â€“ not just for bright-eyed young couples on their wedding day. Because of his blood-earnest, death-defying love, Jesus can bring us all into the ultimate romance. Whatever your relationship history or status, this bliss is for you!

You
beside me.
Me: beside myself with you.
Beyond myself in you,
Become myself anew,
Belongs, this self, to you.

You
behold me.
Me: behold the world in you.
Besotted with the view,
Bewitched by all you do,
Beguiled by guileless you.

We
believe this:
This bedtime tale
Though countless fail
Though pride derail
Though death curtail

We believe this.
This bliss
Besieged by hatredâ€™s hiss
Beset by gravesâ€™ abyss
Betrayed despite our kiss
We believe this.

But is this bliss true?
Or only for the few
And then sinks from view
Is it true?
Beneath the tale,
Before we fail,
Beside whatâ€™s frail,
Beyond deathâ€™s vale?
Is it true?

Not only for the few
And then sinks from view
Is it true?

He
Beheld me.
Me: deep held in my disgrace.
He bends now face to face,
Becomes me in His grace,
Befriends me, takes my place.

He
Betrothed me.
Me: bestowed the world for free.
Bequeathed by royal decree,
Beloved eternally,
Become as one: He with me.

This, beneath all other glories
This, beyond the bedtime stories
This, beside your marital station
This, loveâ€™s sweetest consummation.

This is true.
Never to sink from view.
Not only for the few.
This bliss is for you.

#Valentines #ValentinesDay #Love

title: A Picture Is Worth A Thousand Words: Shining Light On Abortion
description:
Over the centuries, images have had a profound effect on public opinion. From Thomas Clarkson's use of the Brooks Slave Ship diagram and Wedgwood Medallion, to the image of Emmett Till that inspired Rosa Parks, to the photos of children being attacked in Birmingham, Alabama during the civil rights movement, and the images of toddler Aylan Kurdi, the refugee drowned at sea and washed ashore, all of these images have caused intense reaction and moved people to do something about the injustices they depicted.

But today, there is still a terrible injustice going on, all over the world...

title: On Earth As In Heaven - Launch Video (90 seconds)
description:
Watch the full 12 minute documentary here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0tjKNsDzczc

50 years ago the crew of Apollo 8 took the world's first selfie. It was a shot that became known as "earthrise" - the first time we'd seen the world from beyond the horizon of the moon. But man's mission to the heavens was put in perspective by Col. James Irwin: the 8th man on the moon. He said "God walking on the earth is more important than man walking on the moon." God's mission to the earth was the truly costly one. Yet God thought it worth it. This Christmas, marvel at the peace-making mission that puts our quest for the stars in perspective.

title: In the beginning by Glen Scrivener
description:
"In the beginning" is the first of 12 phrases that can take you through the Bible in Glen Scrivener's latest book, "Long Story Short."

https://www.christianfocus.com/products/2758/long-story-short

â€œIn the beginningâ€, ink still wet,
Primeval paths, positioned, set.
Creationâ€™s canopy clipped in place,
Potential fixed in time and space.

What force began that first beginning?
What set the world and galaxies spinning?
What weight subsists beneath all things?
What source from which this splendour springs?

It seems to me you have four choices,
Four competing primal voices.
Something calls the tune above:
Nothing, Chaos, Power or Love?

Now nothing is a strange head-waters,
As old King Lear said to his daughters,
â€œNothing will come of nothingâ€, and yet
Some think nonentities beget.

Unless their â€œnothingâ€s an ancient rumbling,
A giant, cavernous, black, old something,
But if in every sense itâ€™s nought,
Then lifeâ€™s a miracle, absurdly wrought. 

And all our days are spent suspended,
Over the abyss to which weâ€™re tended.
Laughing, learning, living, loving,
But push beneath, itâ€™s really nothing.

Lifeâ€™s a breath and soon exhaled,
The darkness wins, the light has failed.
We burn our lamps but night is crowned.
From blackness born, to blackness bound.

And so to chaos some will turn.
Primeval punch-ups their concern:
Bangs and Blasts and Battles, War,
These begot us in days of yore.

The myths of old saw earth deriving
From the deities conniving.
Warring gods began the trouble,
We are just the cosmic rubble.

Still today we have our clashes,
Life emerges from the ashes,
Of stars exploding, species striving,
The weak devoured, the strong surviving.

And if we live with this regime,
Then selfishness must reign supreme.
Itâ€™s dog eat dog, you get ahead,
Until your toppled, then youâ€™re dead.

But maybe you think life is more
Than endless struggle, pointless war.
Perhaps above the chaos towers,
Some all-controlling cosmic powers.

And â€œIn the beginning...â€ there was the LAW
Of gravity or something more.
This power reigns, all must succumb
And dance to its relentless drum.

And then the faith-head comes along,
Starts to sing the same old song.
â€œThere is a sovereign, we are awed,
Letâ€™s call this boundless power: God.â€

And â€œin the beginningâ€, imagine a throne.
Power personified, all alone.
No back and forth, no give and take,
This Self exists for Selfâ€™s own sake.

If such a god decrees creation,
Creatures have but one relation.
Godâ€™s a cosmic Chairman Mao,
Defined by might his world must bow.

And so religious folk are sated,
Rendering reverence unabated.
From nothing and from chaos saved,
Yet under Power now enslaved.

Is this how Christians see the matter?
God a narcissist to flatter?
If this were true all hopeâ€™s bereft,
But there is another option left.

We read in Genesis and John,
A life of love before the dawn.
A Father, Son and Spirit bound,
In self poured out and, losing, found.

In back and forth these Three delight,
And share one life of radiant light.
Behold: This deferential dance,
This ancient and profound romance. 

This is the bubbling brook that burst
the banks of endless love immersed,
To flood all else with light and longing,
Soak our souls with true belonging.

This: the pulse of all creation,
This: the primitive vibration,
This: all natureâ€™s explanation,
â€œIn the beginningâ€: Adoration. 

Where are the well-adjusted minds?
Which faith to deepest truth aligns?
For all will hold that love is first,
But in their creed the rankâ€™s reversed. 

We live as though self-givingâ€™s best,
We deem a life of service blessed.
We spend our lives as loved and lover,
And then conclude itâ€™s all a cover?

For if nothingâ€™s our source, then lifeâ€™s absurd.
If chaos, then warâ€™s the final word.
If power, then all of us are slaves.
And yet itâ€™s love the whole world craves.

So whatâ€™s our â€œbeginningâ€?  Our answers count.
Both â€˜nowâ€™ and â€˜nextâ€™ spring from this fount.
Which sovereign ruler reigns above?
Nothing, Chaos, Power, or Love?

title: A Funny Thing Happened On The Way To The Tomb
description:
All 3 "Funny Thing" Easter poems: 

A Funny Thing Happened On The Way To The Tomb

Thisâ€™ll make you smile, 
So Godâ€™s dead.
Not the most fertile ground for comedy,
But stick with me a while.
Godâ€™s dead, he bled out on Friday before dusk, a husk of a God, 
Buried in sod, planted in a virgin tomb,
An unpromising womb but I guess thatâ€™s his style.

Now Saturday was a holy day, and anyway everyone needed a rest after killing God,
So they put a day aside to recover from the deicide,
Which brings us to Sunday. 
And there are some women who really want to attend to Godâ€™s corpse,
because of course itâ€™s bad manners to have God rotting in the tomb. 
You should at least perfume the cadaver, 
so they have a journey ahead.

And as they tread this path they disregard pretty much all he said,
Because he told them he was God and death could not hold him. 
So if any were believing they would not be grieving,
Theyâ€™d presume that service would soon resume. 
Theyâ€™d camp beside the tomb and wait for God to self-exhume. 

But no, no-one believed God, not even his believers.
We canâ€™t conceive a Higher Power really.
Not higher than the grave which will devour,
Thatâ€™s the One to make us cower.
That glowering conqueror of light.
Itâ€™s never lost a fight.
Each extinguished breath, 
Declares that death is Lord.
Itâ€™s scored a victory over every rival.

At Godâ€™s arrival we briefly entertained a doubt: â€˜Maybe Lifeâ€™s in with a shout,â€™ 
But on Friday he was out for the count, 
and we went back to perfuming our cadavers. 
Cos all we have, it seems, is corpse preservation regimes.
And so these women resign themselves to a truth alarming:
Even God requires embalming. 

And then, itâ€™s empty. 
He is not there. 
Not in the place where he lay, 
Not in the domain of decay. 
Death made its play, 
But God made a bolder move.

Heâ€™s won. 
Theyâ€™re stunned. 
None dared believe it, 
But now, NOW theyâ€™re crying.
Life has killed death by dying.
Heâ€™s Devoured the beast that swallowed him, 
Crushed the abyss by falling in,
Destroyed destruction from within. 

The Seedâ€™s burst out on Easter morn
The Son from the virgin tomb is born
The valley of shadow receives its dawn
And a hole through death is forever torn.

And these mourners look through, to see Him.
And to see Him is to view Home. 
Home shorn of thorns, 
Home reborn, Home adorned with golden hue.

On Easter Sunday, this the view:
Itâ€™s country walks and heart-warming talks,
Mind-blowing preaches and breakfast on beaches,
Feasting and family and peace and grace,
And Jesus our Battle-Scarred Brother, face to face. 

Maybe we came to the tomb to pretty a corpse and honour the dead. 
But today instead we meet a living God. 
And so, with a tremor in our voices but steel in our bones, 
We dare to step on the monsterâ€™s neck,
As it writhes under a Victorâ€™s blow. 
And in the face of hell we bellow: 
O Grave, Where is your victory, 
O Death, Where is your sting? 

We sing the happily ever after. 
Here begins the Easter laughter.


speaklife.org.uk

title: A Funny Thing Happened On The Way To The Execution
description:
A Funny Thing Happened On The Way To The Execution - some Easter themed stand-up poetry.

Did you hear the one about the God who croaked? 
Itâ€™s kind of a joke. 

Heâ€™s this bloke, shows up broke, 
Among downtrodden folk
Spoke truth, full tilt, words spilt, 
Heâ€™s a Jew doing stand up with a northern lilt.
Built worlds with his words, provoked laughter, stoked rage,
Awoke guilt in the powerful then to assuage,

But his schtick uncloaked the crowd, pricked the proud,
He ploughed dangerous and deep. To the core.
And history saw that when Truth is so uncouth as to speak, we freak. 
In frenzied violence.
Weâ€™re proud to be woke but when God spoke, we choked him to silence.
Thatâ€™s the joke.

Heaven came preaching, earth would not hear
We said â€œShut the hell upâ€, 
Which was his whole idea.
He said: â€œIâ€™ll set you freeâ€, so we put him in chains,
To teach him who or what on earth really reigns.

So God goes on trial, 
the file against himâ€™s thin, but they pile in.
Accusers line up through the night, 
yet none turn out to line up right,

And all the while God pleads the fifth,
An Adamantine monolith.
He will not baulk.
They knock, they mock, they hurl their mud against the rock,
Nothing makes him talk.
And not one accusation sticks,
Except, the one he fixed upon from the start: Heâ€™s God.
Implacably so. 

Well case closed, he has to go.
Whatâ€™s he done? None can say
But for who he is, God must pay.
Hereâ€™s the shock: the Judge is put in the dock
The guilty sit on high
And make their verdict: Life must die.
The Truth is held in contempt of reason.
The King convicted of high treason,
And to cap it all, their genius trick,
Godâ€™s declared a heretic.

So the Mover of worlds is pinned to a stake,
His thirst unslaked, 
His life-blood taken
Earth shaken,
God forsaken.

He turned his cheek, earth clenched its fist
And hammered heavenâ€™s Pacifist.

And the man who drove the nails, the soldier who impales his Maker with a spear,
To him itâ€™s suddenly clear, however odd:
This is what it looks like to be God.
Not a thunderbolt hurled, 
Arms wide open to the world, 
Forgiveness unfurled to his murderers.
This is God. Covered in blood.
This is Good.
Good Friday, if you credit it, 
Good news, if you let it. 
A good joke, if you get it.

speaklife.org.uk

title: A Funny Thing Happened On The Way To Jerusalem
description:
A Funny Thing Happened On The Way To Jerusalem - some Easter themed stand-up poetry.

So thereâ€™s this guy who says that heâ€™s God. 
Repeatedly. 
And heâ€™s not a fraud. He is the still centre of sanity
No sliver of vanity, Purest humanity.
But heâ€™s God.
And he needs you to know that heâ€™s God â€” 
God on a mission â€”
Heâ€™s got a real Messiah complex. 
The original condition. 
A messiah complex with a death wish and thatâ€™s the joke. 
Cos when he spoke his claim, all would complain, crying â€œProve it!â€ 
And he says: â€˜Iâ€™ll show you Iâ€™m God, Watch me die.â€™ Which is odd as a sign of deity. 
But he doesnâ€™t just say it, he hurls himself fierce at the grave,
Declaring that this is the behaviour of divinity.

Heâ€™ll assert his infinity by choking to death, to croak his last breath in rasping benediction.
Heâ€™s the Fountain of Life and the clearest depiction His convictionâ€™s non-fiction is a cry of dereliction. One hell of a crucifixion.

Thereâ€™s this guy and heâ€™s God and he must die, on this heâ€™ll insist.
Itâ€™s the item on his bucket list.
Heâ€™s Messiah with a death-wish and
While for us the goal of â€œDyingâ€ would represent a distinct lack of ambition,
For him itâ€™s his mission.
To be slain as a Lamb:
He said â€œWhen Iâ€™m lifted up, then youâ€™ll know that I AM.â€ That I AM WHO I AM. 
Then youâ€™ll know itâ€™s not a scam. 
To see him damned by earth, hell and heaven
Then comes recognition: hereâ€™s the definition of glory.

So in the story this King marches to his throne, 
his face set like stone, 
to ascend the hill, and assert his will, to reign in state.
Protocol dictates he should ride a steed, 
Of noble breed, perhaps a stallion, and, behind, his battalion and so to his office accede.

But hereâ€™s the thing. This King rides a donkey. Or two â€“â€“ 
So Matthew reckoned, he remembers a second,
An old cloak laid astride these poor brutes side by side.
So picture the scene. Lining the road: Israelâ€™s people and priests, 
And God all-precarious atop these two beasts.
A royal charade,
A half-assed parade.
 
And theyâ€™re hailing him King,
And he looks like a fool, And still he rides on, the irony cruel
Cos he knows that the crowd enraptured in praise
Will bay for his blood in a matter of days.
But still he rides down this road, he cannot be slowed,
On this trajectory locked, he will be mocked and forlorn,
His figure torn, 
majesty shorn, 
Crowned by thorns, 
With nails adorned, 
Enthroned in scorn,
His kingdom borne across trembling shoulders.
And yet on he soldiers.
 
For this is his divine vocation, 
Decidedly not an assassination,
Somehow itâ€™s his coronation,
Because here the Fountain is comprehended 
When we see it full-expended,
In death the Life-Spring, crimson poured
Becomes the proof that He is Lord.

So on he rides in asinine glory.
Easter is a funny story.

title: Meet the Nativity: The Story Behind Episode 3
description:
If you haven't seen it already, watch Meet the Nativity: Episode 3: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lt1syh64seE

Claim your free Christmas book at MeetTheNativity.com


Ruth, the stepmother, is another outsider at Christmas. Like Will, the boyfriend, she too feels estranged â€“ from the heart of the family and from the joy she's "meant" to feel at this most wonderful time of the year. It's not a wonderful time for Ruth. In fact Christmas is particularly hard for her. And she copes the only way she knows how, by taking control of her immediate circumstances â€“ the house, the food, the decorations â€“ becoming a whirl of frenzied activity. She's doing her best but feeling far from Christmas joy.

Ruth's story reflects the story of so many. We feel we need to be full of Christmas cheer yet, for any number of reasons, it may be a particularly hard season for us. How do we cope? Perhaps we try to take control, to order the chaos, to "tidy things up a bit." It never works. We end up feeling fed up, under-appreciated and surrounded by mess.

But Ruth 'meets the nativity', and there she discovers a Christmas joy that enters into our chaos. "That baby should not be here" she cries and she's right. God the Son ought not to stoop to such circumstances. He belongs on a throne, not wriggling on straw in a cold and hostile world. But there he is. And he's offered to Ruth.

She objects: "My hands are dirty", but he doesn't seem to mind. He's given anyway. And finally, as Ruth receives this ultimate Christmas gift, she is still. As she had exclaimed in exasperation to the vicar, now she says to Christ: "Welcome to the mess." What mess? The mess of the stable, the mess of the world, the mess of our lives and hearts that can never be clean and tidy the way we might want. "Welcome to the mess" we say, and as the carol says: "Where meek souls will receive him still, the dear Christ enters in."

This Christmas, there's one guest you don't have to tidy up for. His whole mission is to enter our mess, to be received by dirty-handed failures like you and me, to take that dirt on himself on the cross and to offer us true peace. When we grasp this then we can finish the carol:

O Holy Child of Bethlehem, descend to us we pray.
Cast out our sin and enter in, be born in us today,
We hear the Christmas angels,
The great glad tidings tell.
O come to us, abide with us,
Our Lord Emmanuel.




MeetTheNativity.com

title: Our hearts united (The third 321 video)
description:
QUESTIONS FOR REFLECTION:

What has been your impression of â€˜the Christian lifeâ€™? Has this video challenged that at all?

What have been your experiences with church? The bible? Prayer?

How do these things relate to â€œoneness with Jesusâ€?

What would it look like for you to be one with Jesus? (Think big. Think specifics.)

title: The world divided (The second 321 video)
description:
QUESTIONS FOR REFLECTION:

Do you think itâ€™s true that our families play a big part in shaping our identity? Why or why not?

What do you think about the human family? Do you think weâ€™re in a pit?

What do you make of Jesus? Why do you think He came?

Does this teaching on â€œAdam and Christâ€ help explain why Jesus came?

title: The God of love (The first 321 video)
description:

What do you think was there â€œin the beginningâ€?

How do you think our understanding of â€œthe beginningâ€ affects our view of life here and now?

The video speaks of the Trinity as â€œThree Persons united in loveâ€. 
Does this picture of God challenge the way you normally think about God? How so?

Given this picture of God â€“ what do you think God wants from us?
